pages.text: In War Dance $(thing)parrying$() is as simple as holding a registered weapon in your main or offhand and facing your attacker when they try to melee attack you.$(br)If done correctly you will hear a $(l)clang$() and damage will be negated.$(br2)A $(o)Configured weapon$() means any item which displays values such as $(o)"posture per attack" and "Defense posture multiplier"$() as part of their tooltips.

When parrying: posture damage is instead taken based on either the mob's computed posture damage $(o)(usually based on it's size and damage or preconfigured values in the configs)$() or their held weapon. $(br)The posture damage taken is further modified by the $(l)Defense$() value of the user's weapon as a percentage.$(br2) So if you were meant to take 5 posture damage, but had a 0.8 multiplier in defense, that hit should only deal around 4 posture damage when parried.

Most weapons however will not parry projectile based attacks such as arrows from skeletons or pillagers. $(br2)To automatically parry and deflect projectiles you need to use items marked as $(#FFD810)shields$().$(br)Which is usually restricted to actual shields of varying sizes, crossbows, large books and certain massive swords. Later it may also include doors, trapdoors and signs.

Some projectiles such as those $(o)enchanted with piercing, those which explode or are magical in nature$() may not be parryable either. But depending on the mods and how they're made, all you can really do is simply test such projectiles or potentially configure via the configs. $(o)(if you do make some configs. consider sending them in to help everyone. :) )
